p.s: The expert from the speech Remarks of president Barack Obama at student roundtable is given by Barack Obama at the 7th April 2009 during a visit to Istanbul, where he hosted a students roundtable at the Culture and Arts Center of Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University in Tophane.
The speech is given for young people to support them to get experience with different cultures, languages and lifestyles.
But the speech should also inspire young people to do a student exchanges.
Barack Obama is the opinion that intercultural understanding is really important and he would like to create cohesion between the world.

One Argumentargument is that he's deeply committed to rebuilding a relationship between the United States and the people of the Muslim world (ll. 1, 2) but one that's grounded in mutual interest and mutual respect (ll. 2, 3).

The speaker likes it to see a new spirit of activism and responsibility (l. 4), his given examples where he havehas seen it is in young Americans who are choosing to teach in our schools or volunteer abroad (l. 5) but also in his presidential campaign where young people provided the energy and the idealism that made effort possible (l. 6).
One more example are travelling abroad (l. 7) and the speaking to groups (l. 7).

His motivation to give speechsspeeches like this is to find new ways to connect young Americans to young people all around the world (ll. 9/10) in form of supporting opportunities to learn new languages (l. 10) serve and study (l. 10) and welcoming students from other countries (l. 10/11).
He called it a critical part of how America engages the world (l. 11/12).
In his view simple exchanges can break down walls (l. 13), when people come together (l. 13) and speak to one other (l. 13/14) or share common experience (l. 14).
This important to don't forget common humanity (l. 14) is really important and we're joined together by all pursuit of a life that's productive and purposeful (l. 15).
The greatest thing that could happen is when mistrust begins to fade (l. 16) and our smaller differences no longer overshadow the things that we share (ll. 16/17).

At the end he inviteinvites the publicum to choose to build new bridges instead of building new walls (l. 18/19), to put aside longstanding division in pursuit of lasting peace (ll. 19/20), and advance a picspelity that is shared by all people and not just the wealthy few (ll. 20/21).
He promises that everyone will find in these endeavors (l. 21) a partner and a supporter and a friend in the United States of America (ll. 21/22).
